title: Horncastle Canal and River Walk Route

images.title: Richard Croft / Horncastle Canal
images.caption: Canal view in the town centre.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Mouth of the Horncastle Canal
images.caption: Mouth of the Horncastle Canal. The Horncastle Canal provided an outlet for agricultural produce from the Horncastle area, linking the town to the navigable River Witham. The Canal was closed in 1889 and is now completely severed from the river, but parts are still in water. The first stretch can just be seen over the top of the bank.

images.title: Dave Hitchborne / South Basin of the Horncastle Canal, Horncastle
images.caption: South Basin of the Horncastle Canal. Looking towards the Bull Ring.

images.title: trevor willis / Footbridge over disused Horncastle canal
images.caption: Footbridge over disused Horncastle canal. Kirkby on Bain church can be seen in the background

images.title: Richard Croft / Horncastle Canal, North basin
images.caption: North basin View towards Bridge Street from Hares Warehouse on the River Bain

images.title: Richard Croft / River Bain
images.caption: Canalised stretch of the River Bain as the disused Horncastle Canal, seen from Haltham lock bridge

images.title: Dave Hitchborne / Bull Ring, Horncastle
images.caption: Bull Ring, Horncastle. At centre, the shot includes Wilkin Chapman Solicitors, the former Lloyds Bank building, which stands on the corner of Bank Street.

description: This walk takes you along the old Horncastle Canal and the River Bain from the town centre of this Lincolnshire town. From here you can pick up the Viking Way, a waymarked footpath which will take you south along a section of the old canal. It originally ran for 11 miles from the River Witham at Dogdyke to Horncastle, through twelve locks largely following the course of River Bain. The canal opened in 1802, and was abandoned for navigation in 1889. This walk runs for the first couple of miles along the waterway, finishing near Martin. You could extend the walk by continuing south through Roughton to Haltham and Kirkby On Bain where there's a noteworthy 16th century pub and an ancient Norman church to see.
